Answer: As of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejectiAs of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejection. Even if the heart is rejected and the donor dies, what we learn from the process will enable us to succeed the next time. I reckon this will become the mainstream way we get spare parts by the end of the decade in an optimistic scenario, by the end of the next decade in the pessimistic one.Either way, the moment is as groundbreaking as December 3rd, 1967, when the first human heart ever was transplanted, ushering the era of organ transplants of today. That patient died after 18 days, I hope this guy does better.

Answer: The current level of technology means at least 1–2 centuries, likely more, before we will be able to get to the nearest stars to the Solar System. Unless we have a major breakthrough in Light Speed Travel, or possible FTL Travel, the only other option is multi-generational long distance travel, likely with cryogenic sleep for the travelers. This will still require a serious advancement from current technology.

Answer: After you’ve accepted the offer, what’s the point? If other companies offer you something much more, and you go for them, you would have to back off from your initial offer. They’d probably started the paperwork already, so you’d waste their time. If you absolutely know you’re gonna work for the first company, don’t waste time of the others. Like the bottomline here is - don’t waste time (neither yours, nor others).The way I deal with these is I’m telling upfront that hey, I’m currently interviewing with others as well, and I’d like to see all the options I can before I reply definitely to youAfter you’ve accepted the offer, what’s the point? If other companies offer you something much more, and you go for them, you would have to back off from your initial offer. They’d probably started the paperwork already, so you’d waste their time. If you absolutely know you’re gonna work for the first company, don’t waste time of the others. Like the bottomline here is - don’t waste time (neither yours, nor others).The way I deal with these is I’m telling upfront that hey, I’m currently interviewing with others as well, and I’d like to see all the options I can before I reply definitely to your offer. That may be another “cultural fit” test: I’ve heard of companies that would revoke their offer because “we’re looking for people that really WANT to work for us, if you don’t accept immediately, it’s not on the table anymore”. There’s no way I’m going to be employed there, as long as I have choice. Usually, though, people are pretty chill; and if it turns out that I choose other company over them, maybe they’ll enhance their compensation package so the accept rate is better in the future?In the end, nothing of it is personal in any way, it’s just business as usual. Just don’t waste anybody’s time.

I don't give a blind try to any interview.If you get multiple offers you will have a backup plan if something goes wrong. I hate to work with a feeling of job insecurity. I should be able to resign at any point of time without thinking about my next job. It is possible only if you are able to clear anyNot at all. I will attend each and every interview even a day before my joining date in the new organization. I feel extremely confident and happy when I clear an interview. I usually list out the topics and practice on the questions of the failed interviews. Yes, I prepare for every interview. I don't give a blind try to any interview.If you get multiple offers you will have a backup plan if something goes wrong. I hate to work with a feeling of job insecurity. I should be able to resign at any point of time without thinking about my next job. It is possible only if you are able to clear any interview at any point of time. I actually did it an year ago. I couldn't fit myself into 12hrs working model in my previous job. I resigned without having any offer in hand. I was able to get 8 offers within 3 weeks of my resignation. It happened just because of practice.I give equal preference to both small and big company interviews. Generally big company interviews are easy to get through. Mid level company interviews are tough. Hope this helps you!!

Or at least call ahead and let them know, and give them the option. (‘I just accepted an offer from xxx. Or at least call ahead and let them know, and give them the option. (‘I just accepted an offer from xxx. I'd still like to meet and chat - we might do business in the future, and I'll pay for my own lunch and travel - but if you want to cancel, I certainly don't want to waste your time.’)Busy people get REALLY pissed if you waste their time to no benefit. There's a good chance you'll run into the same people in the future - and some people have long memories.Think of it like junk mail. If you're going to shove stuff in my mailbox, at least wrap it in a magazine that I might want to leaf through.

Answer: I have a story that’s related to this question. But to be fair, while I’m in engineering it’s not software, and my tale isn’t about getting a job.For me it was trying to figure out what my college major was.In High school I had loved Biology. A Lot. I’m one of those weird people that read theI wanted to be a geneticist. But when I got to College the biology department was so infused with political crap that I couldn’t hack it and I decided I needI have a story that’s related to this question. But to be fair, while I’m in engineering it’s not software, and my tale isn’t about getting a job.For me it was trying to figure out what my college major was.In High school I had loved Biology. A Lot. I’m one of those weird people that read theI wanted to be a geneticist. But when I got to College the biology department was so infused with political crap that I couldn’t hack it and I decided I needed to change. So I set up a bunch of interviews with college heads to discuss such a change.I set up a meeting with the dean of Chemistry, and one with an Engineering councilor. Chemistry was early int he day and the Engineering was later that afternoon.I met with the Chemistry person. He made it sound really exciting. Chemistry was a pretty big part of Biology and I had enjoyed Chemistry quite a bit even taking extra labs at that very university as a High school student to get ahead. When I walked out of the interview I wanted to sign up for Chemistry as my major. It was a couple hours before my next interview and figured my mind was already made up and I would simply blow it off.Then I remembered people in my past who blew off interviews or whatever and I hated that so I decided to call and see if they could see me earlier.It was there that I discovered Mechanical Engineering and I’ve never looked back.Always go to all your interviews.

It wasn’t a permanent position; it was a contract job. But I got the gig.Two jobs ago, I just met with three other engineers in a conference room for about an hour. They didn’t ask many questions, because I speYes, often.It doesn’t have anything to do with my extreme proficiency at programming (maybe), but all companies are different.Four gigs ago I got offered the job after about an hour of interviews with four different people. After some pretty easy programming questions, I got an offer the next day.Three gigs ago, I just had a chat with the lead engineer for about 45 minutes on the phone. It wasn’t a permanent position; it was a contract job. But I got the gig.Two jobs ago, I just met with three other engineers in a conference room for about an hour. They didn’t ask many questions, because I spent a lot of time telling them about my last project. Later that day: offer.For my current gig, I just talked to the tech director and his second in command. The WebEx interview was supposed to last 45 minutes. It went on for 90. Next day: offer.The thing is, most of these were fairly small companies. My previous gig was a big corporation, but with a rather small software division.Bigger software companies like Microsoft and FAANG tend to have multiple rounds of interviews. Smaller ones tend to be faster and shorter.

Answer: No, Apple will increasingly fall behind Google.It is becoming clear that AI will have a huge role in the future of devices. Google Assistant can already do things like adding hotel and plane reservations to your calendar. Google Photos can identify people in your pictures and automatically share the photos. Fairly soon it will be able to do things like automatically rescheduling meetings, picking a restaurant for you to have dinner at and making a reservation there, and perhaps even handling simple financial transactions like paying bills. In general, what we do today in apps will be done by ANo, Apple will increasingly fall behind Google.It is becoming clear that AI will have a huge role in the future of devices. Google Assistant can already do things like adding hotel and plane reservations to your calendar. Google Photos can identify people in your pictures and automatically share the photos. Fairly soon it will be able to do things like automatically rescheduling meetings, picking a restaurant for you to have dinner at and making a reservation there, and perhaps even handling simple financial transactions like paying bills. In general, what we do today in apps will be done by AI in the near future (<5 years).This plays to Google' strong suit. AI is one of its most core competencies. Apple's strongest suit is design, but AI reduces its importance because users will not have to interact as much with the OS. Apple will still make and sell beautiful phones, and will retain a huge share of the market, but Google will pull away technologically within 5 years and in market share in about 10. Apple already lags way behind Google and Amazon in the assistant speaker market.Software eats the world. - Marc Andreessen

Answer: I went to both Google I/O and WWDC in both 2013 and 2014. The difference in the two companies' atmospheres is pretty interesting to see, but at a high level the content is fairly similar.Google I/O feels a bit like a high-tech fair. There are booths set up around the Moscone Center floor, and everything is loud, colorful, fun, and energetic. You can play innovative video games and try demos of new products. Some of the presentations actually happen at the booths, which causes logistical issues when they're unexpectedly popular. The food is great, in typical Google style. You get shiny free gadI went to both Google I/O and WWDC in both 2013 and 2014. The difference in the two companies' atmospheres is pretty interesting to see, but at a high level the content is fairly similar.Google I/O feels a bit like a high-tech fair. There are booths set up around the Moscone Center floor, and everything is loud, colorful, fun, and energetic. You can play innovative video games and try demos of new products. Some of the presentations actually happen at the booths, which causes logistical issues when they're unexpectedly popular. The food is great, in typical Google style. You get shiny free gadgets to take home and develop on.WWDC feels more corporate and efficient. Apple clearly invests more time and energy in the logistics and details of the event. There is nothing of interest outside the presentation rooms, and the Moscone Center floor is used as a queueing area to transfer people in and out of rooms in a maximally efficient manner. The conference is significantly longer, so the pace feels less frenetic, and they have time for cool guest speakers like Bill Nye. The food is not great. There are no free gadgets.Stylistic differences aside, the content of the presentations is actually pretty similar. Here are the major categories of talks that appear at both conferences, ordered from worst to best:
